Exterior Door Maintenance:
All exterior doors require routine caulking maintenance as do all windows. At least once a year, you should plan to check caulking at all points of the door unit. Pay particular attention to any moulding that comes in contact with siding or brick, as most leaks occur in these areas. Carefully remove any loosened or gapped caulking, and then apply new caulking in that area.

Hinge screws should be tightened to keep the door from binding. (Tip: if a screw is "stripped" or no longer will keep a tight hold in the hole, take the screw out. Apply a liberal amount of wood glue to a wooden match stick and force this into the "stripped" screw hole. An additional "toothpick" may sometimes be needed to properly fill the hole. Allow approximately 1/2 hour for drying then re-install the screw)
Be sure to check the threshold on all exterior doors a minimum of twice per year (mid spring & late fall). As outside temperatures change, the metal or wood material that a door frame is made from will expand or shrink. Closely observe the door in a closed position. If excessive daylight is visible from underneath, the threshold should be adjusted.

To adjust a "floating door threshold" follow these steps:

1) Remove any cap that may cover the threshold screws or mechanisim.

2) Insert a screwdriver into the slot provided and turn to raise or lower the threshold to firmly seat against the bottom of the door sweep.

3) Using a garden hose, simulate a normal rainfall against the bottom of the door. Someone should be on the other side of the door with a towel to observe is water is coming underneath the door. If there is not a leak, you have correctly adjusted the threshold. If water does come though, repeat the steps above to obtain a tighter seal.

(Note: Do not spray the water too hard. Remember, you are simulating a "normal" rainfall. If the threshold is adjusted too tight, the rubber doorsweep attached to the bottom of the door will wear out prematurely)
